Detailed Description

MySQL connectivity class.

Description

This class acts as a handle for connecting to a MySQL database. PHP has 2 primary ways of doing this with different drivers, see MySQL vs MySQLi for more information.

Usage

Use this class to connect to a local or remote MySQL database. The constructor takes a URI and uses the extracted details to make the connection. See CMMySQL().

Example 1: Connecting to a MySQL database.

 // connect
 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://bob:abc123@localhost/mydb");
 if($dbh->error())
   die("Could not connect to the database: " . $dbh->error());

Example 2: Query data from a table.

There are two ways of doing this, the first is to iterate the data - that is to only select the data as you intent to process it. This is the most common way: 

 // iterating data
 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable where id between ? and ?", array(5, 10));
 while($r = $q->fetch()) {
   print_r($r);
 }

The second way to fetch all the of the data into a single array. This is useful when using small selects or data that you need ot process many times. Just be careful, this method requies your PHP to be able to allocate enough RAM to hold the entire result set. 

 // all-in-one line
 $all = $dbh->query("select * from mytable")->fetchAll();

MySQL vs MySQLi

PHP 5+ encourages the use of the mysqli_ functions, but this is an extension that does not come standard with all PHP distibutions and is not easy to install in shared environments. For this reason CMMySQL will automatically choose the best driver when a connection is created - first selecting MySQLi if it is available or falling back to the standard MySQL API if not.

Member Function Documentation

availableMethods (  ) 

Get available protocol methods. 

 $features = $dbh->availableMethods();
 if(in_array($features, 'getDatabaseTables'))
     $q = $dbh->getDatabaseTables();
 else echo "Uh-oh, getDatabaseTables() has not been implemented for {$dbh->engine()}";

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

bindValues ( $  sql,
$  values = false 
)

Internal use for binding value in SQL statements.

Use internally by query() and insert() for substituting values. 

 select * from mytable where id=? and name=?

to 

 select * from mytable where id='3' and name='Bob'
Parameters:
$sql SQL
$values An non-associative array of values to escape and substitute.
Returns:
Substituted string that is automatically escaped.
See also:
query()
execute()
insert()

Definition at line 1051 of file CMMySQL.php.

CMMySQL ( $  uri,
$  a = false 
)

Connect to a MySQL database.

Database connections are made with a URI like; 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://username:password@host:port/dbname");
 if($dbh->error())
   die("Oh no! The error was " . $dbh->error());
host using MySQLi
Can be either a host name or an IP address. When possible, pipes will be used instead of the TCP/IP protocol.
Prepending host by p: opens a persistent connection. changeUser() is automatically called on connections opened from the connection pool.
user
The MySQL user name.
password
If not provided, the MySQL server will attempt to authenticate the user against those user records which have no password only. This allows one username to be used with different permissions (depending on if a password as provided or not).
dbname
If provided will specify the default database to be used when performing queries.
port
Specifies the port number to attempt to connect to the MySQL server. If this is not provided 3306 (the default MySQL server port) will be used.

If the mysql driver is used and the username and/or password is not provided the values are taken from mysql.default_user and mysql.default_password respectivly. Unless PHP SQL safe mode is activated, then the default values are ignored.

You can use $a['error'] to assign a different error stack before it makes the connection. 

 $e = new CMError();
 $e->setVerboseLevel(CMErrorType::Fatal);
 $fail = new CMMySQL("mysql://blabla@localhost/blabla", array('error' => $e));
 $errors = $e->errors();
Note:
MySQLi custom socket path is not supported yet.
Parameters:
$uri URI string.
$a Assign extra attributes or actions. See table above.
Returns:
A new CMMySQL object will always be returned regardless of if the connection is successfull.

Definition at line 579 of file CMMySQL.php.

commit (  ) 

Commit transaction.

Commit a transaction. In most cases you will have to turn autocommit off before passing your SQL stataments with setAutoCommit(false).

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Note:
This method will still return true for engines that are not transactional, such as MyISAM.
Returns:
true on success, false if the transaction could not be commited.
See also:
setAutoCommit()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1094 of file CMMySQL.php.

delete ( $  tableName,
$  criteria = false,
$  a = false 
)

MySQL DELETE.

This uses a key-value paired array to construct a DELETE statement like: 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://root:abc123@localhost/test");
 $insertID = $dbh->update('mytable', array(
               'firstname' => 'Robert',
               'value' => 45
             ), array(
               'firstname' => 'Bob',
               'lastname' => 'Smith'
             );
 // SQL executed: UPDATE mytable
 //               SET firstname='Robert', value='45'
 //               WHERE firstname='Bob' AND lastname='Smith'
Note:
Your fields will be safely escaped automatically, if you want a value to be binded that is not escaped see CMConstant class.
This method can still return 0 rows affected as a successful result. If you want to test the execution success compare it with false. 
       if($dbh->update(...) === false)
        die("FAILED!");
Parameters:
$tableName The table name.
$criteria An associaive array of criteria to filter the UPDATE.
$a Extra options to pass directly to query()
Returns:
The number of rows affected by teh update will be return, otherwise false.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

engine (  ) 

Get the database product name.

Definition at line 1508 of file CMMySQL.php.

eraseTable ( $  tableName  ) 

Erase (not truncate) a table.

Erasing a table removes all the entries of the table without affecting the auto incrementing columns. It is effectivly: 

 DELETE FROM $tableName WHERE 1;
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table.
Returns:
true for success, otherwise false (such as if the table doesn't exist or you do not have adequate privileges.)
See also:
truncateTable()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1533 of file CMMySQL.php.

escapeString ( $  str  ) 

Escapes special characters in a string for use in a SQL statement.

Escapes special characters in a string for use in a SQL statement, taking into account the current charset of the connection.

Parameters:
$str The string to be escaped. Characters encoded are NUL (ASCII 0), \n, \r, \, ', ", and Control-Z.
Returns:
Returns an escaped string.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

)

$sql SQL

Definition at line 970 of file CMMySQL.php.

getClientVersion (  ) 

Get MySQL client info.

This is useful to quickly determine the version of the client library to know if some capability exits.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
A number that represents the MySQL client library version in format: main_version*10000 + minor_version *100 + sub_version. For example, 4.1.0 is returned as 40100.

Definition at line 992 of file CMMySQL.php.

getServerVersion (  ) 

Returns the version of the MySQL server as an integer.

The serverVersion() function returns the version of the server connected to (represented by the link parameter) as an integer.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
An integer representing the server version. The form of this version number is main_version * 10000 + minor_version * 100 + sub_version (i.e. version 4.1.0 is 40100).

Definition at line 955 of file CMMySQL.php.

getStatus (  ) 

Gets the current system status.

status() returns a string containing information similar to that provided by the mysqladmin status command. This includes uptime in seconds and the number of running threads, questions, reloads, and open tables.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
A string describing the server status. false if an error occurred.

$schema MySQL does not support schemas so this value has no effect.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 833 of file CMMySQL.php.

getThreadID (  ) 

Returns the thread ID for the current connection.

The threadID() function returns the thread ID for the current connection which can then be killed using killThread() function. If the connection is lost and you reconnect with ping(), the thread ID will be different. Therefore you should get the thread ID only when you need it.

Note:
The thread ID is assigned on a connection-by-connection basis. Hence, if the connection is broken and then re-established a new thread ID will be assigned. To kill a running query you can use the SQL command KILL QUERY processid.
Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
Returns the Thread ID for the current connection.

Definition at line 1466 of file CMMySQL.php.

Returns the number of warnings from the last query in the connection.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
Number of warnings or zero if there are no warnings.
See also:
getWarnings()

Definition at line 1241 of file CMMySQL.php.

insert ( $  tableName,
$  kv = false,
$  a = false 
)

MySQL INSERT.

This uses a key-value paired array to construct an INSERT statement like: 

 $dbh->insert('mytable', array('a' => 'Something', 'b' => 123.45));

Will produce and execute the following SQL: 

 insert into mytable (a, b) values ('Something', '123.45')
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). When the query fails. 'sql' attribute attached with raw SQL.
Parameters:
$tableName The table name.
$kv An associaive array of field names and their respective values.
$a See Query options
Returns:
If the insert was successful the last insert ID will be returned. If the query was not successful 0 will be returned.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

isConnected (  )

Definition at line 1306 of file CMMySQL.php.

query ( $  sql,
$  values = false,
$  a = false 
)

Perform a query on the database that returns a handle to iterate the results.

Example 

 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable");
 if($q->error())
   die("Query failed: " . $q->error());
Note:
When using mysql driver: mysql_query() sends a unique query (multiple queries are not supported) to the currently active database on the server.
For actions that do not require a result use execute().
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). When the query fails. 'sql' attribute attached with raw SQL.
Parameters:
$sql SQL, this can contain bind marks for $values. The query string should not end with a semicolon. Data inside the query should be properly escaped (you should use the binding).
$values An non-associative array of values to substitute into the SQL statement. If there is only one value to substitute this does not need to be an array.
$a An associative array of server options for the query.
Returns:
A new CMMySQLQuery is always returned regarless of if the query fails.
See also:
execute()
insert()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 657 of file CMMySQL.php.

rollback (  ) 

Rolls back current transaction.

Somewhat opposite to the commit() function, this allows a transaction to be rolled back.

Note:
In most cases you must remember to turn autocommit off or else rollback() will not have a transaction to rollback on.
This method will still return true for engines that are not transactional. Such as MyISAM.
Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
true on success, false if the transaction could not be rolled back.
See also:
setAutoCommit()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1345 of file CMMySQL.php.

selectDatabase ( $  dbname,
$  a = false 
)

Change the active database.

In most cases it is easier to set the active database when creating the connection, such: 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://bob:abc123@localhost/mydb");

In the above example the active database will be set to mydb.

Parameters:
$dbname New database name.
$a Does not do anything right now, but is there for future versions.
Returns:
true if success, otherwise false.

Definition at line 774 of file CMMySQL.php.

setAutoCommit ( $  mode = false  ) 

Turn on/off auto commit.

For tranactional database engines. This is used for manual commiting, when inserting large sets of data or snapshot information its is recommented you turn autocommit off and manually commit the transaction. This will be faster and more consistent.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Parameters:
$mode Can be any value that will be evaluated to true or false according to the rules of PHP and the type of argument provided.
Returns:
true if the change was made/available, otherwise false.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1035 of file CMMySQL.php.

setCharacterSet ( $  charset  ) 

Sets the default client character set.

Sets the default character set to be used when sending data from and to the database server.

Note:
To use this function on a Windows platform you need MySQL client library version 4.1.11 or above (for MySQL 5.0 you need 5.0.6 or above).
This is the preferred way to change the charset. Using CMMySQL::query() to execute SET NAMES .. is not recommended.
Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Parameters:
$charset The charset to be set as default.

Definition at line 1383 of file CMMySQL.php.

setLocalInfileHandler ( $  readFunction  ) 

Set callback function for LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE command.

Set callback function for LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE command

The callbacks task is to read input from the file specified in the LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE and to reformat it into the format understood by LOAD DATA INFILE.

The returned data needs to match the format specified in the LOAD DATA.

Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Parameters:
$readFunction The callback function should return the number of characters stored in the buffer or a negative value if an error occurred.

Definition at line 1405 of file CMMySQL.php.

setOption ( $  option,
$  value 
)

Set option.

$option can be one of the following values:

MYSQLI_OPT_CONNECT_TIMEOUT Connection timeout in seconds (supported on Windows with TCP/IP since PHP 5.3.1)
MYSQLI_OPT_LOCAL_INFILE Enable/disable use of LOAD LOCAL INFILE
MYSQLI_INIT_COMMAND Command to execute after when connecting to MySQL server
MYSQLI_READ_DEFAULT_FILE Read options from named option file instead of my.cnf
MYSQLI_READ_DEFAULT_GROUP Read options from the named group from my.cnf or the file specified with MYSQL_READ_DEFAULT_FILE.
Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Parameters:
$option The option that you want to set.
$value The value for the option.
Returns:
Returns true on success or false on failure.

Definition at line 505 of file CMMySQL.php.

SQLState (  ) 

Returns the SQLSTATE error from previous MySQL operation.

Returns a string containing the SQLSTATE error code for the last error. The error code consists of five characters. '00000' means no error. The values are specified by ANSI SQL and ODBC. For a list of possible values, see http://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql/en/error-handling.html.

Note:
Note that not all MySQL errors are yet mapped to SQLSTATE's. The value HY000 (general error) is used for unmapped errors.
Throws a CMError Unavailable
See CMError::throwUnavailable(). If using older MySQL driver. See MySQL vs MySQLi
Returns:
Returns a string containing the SQLSTATE error code for the last error. The error code consists of five characters. '00000' means no error.

Definition at line 842 of file CMMySQL.php.

truncateTable ( $  tableName  ) 

Truncate (not erase) a table.

Truncate will not only delete the data in the table but also reset auto incrementing columns. It is effectivly: 

 TRUNCATE $tableName;
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table.
Returns:
true for success, otherwise false (such as if the table doesn't exist or you do not have adequate privileges.)
See also:
eraseTable()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1556 of file CMMySQL.php.

update ( $  tableName,
$  newvalues,
$  criteria = false,
$  a = false 
)

MySQL UPDATE.

This uses a key-value paired array to construct an UPDATE statement like: 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://root:abc123@localhost/test");
 $affectedRows = $dbh->update('mytable', array(
                  'firstname' => 'Robert',
                  'value' => 45
               ), array(
                  'firstname' => 'Bob',
                  'lastname' => 'Smith'
               );
 // SQL executed: UPDATE mytable
 //               SET firstname='Robert', value='45'
 //               WHERE firstname='Bob' AND lastname='Smith'
Note:
Your fields will be safely escaped automatically, if you want a value to be binded that is not escaped see CMConstant class.
This method can still return 0 rows affected as a successful result. If you want to test the execution success compare it with false. 
       if($dbh->update(...) === false)
        die("FAILED!");
Parameters:
$tableName The table name.
$newvalues An associative array of new values.
$criteria An associaive array of criteria to filter the UPDATE.
$a Extra options to pass directly to query()
Returns:
The number of rows affected by teh update will be return, otherwise false.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.
